newsitem.title: INDIA: High capital gains boost India ICICI net.
newsitem.headline: High capital gains boost India ICICI net.

text.p: High capital gains and low tax provisions helped the Industrial Credit and Investment Corporation of India (ICICI) post a higher than expected 1996/97 (April-March) net profit, analysts said.
Earlier this year, ICICI merged with another term-lender, SCICI, in a deal that took effect from April 1, 1996.
ICICI announced on Monday its post-merger net profit surged 62 percent to 7.7 billion rupees, outperforming analysts expectations of around 6.6-6.7 billion.
On the Bombay Stock Exchange, ICICI closed three percent higher at 59.50 rupees, up 1.75 from Friday's close. In kerb trading the stock made further headway, trading at 63 rupees.
Loans by India's second largest term lender totalled 111.81 billion rupees during the year.
In 1995/96 ICICI posted a net profit of 4.74 billion rupees.

"The higher net profit seems to be on account of high capital gains," said Amit Rajpal, banking analyst at Prime Broking. "We had anticipated lower capital gains, given the depressed nature of the capital market."
ICICI validated the analysts conclusion in a statement issued along with its results to the press but said an acitve portfolio management approach helped it book record gains.
"The year 1996/97 was characterised by a predominant phase of bearish stock market sentiment," it said.
"Against such a backdrop, ICICI booked a record level of capital gains of 1.08 billion rupees."
Rajpal said he had estimated capital gains of around 700 million rupees.

Other factors which helped ICICI post a high net profit included tax provision which were around 100-150 million rupees lower than expected and an increase in dividend income on investments, Rajpal said.
The Bombay blue chip said profit after tax, but before adjustments, rose to 7.52 billion rupees from 4.36 billion.
It posted an earnings per share (EPS) of 16.30 rupees, and gave a dividend of 4.5 rupees per share of 10 rupees face value.
